subject: Communication
title: Proxemics: The Four Distance Zones
description: Learn Proxemics: The Four Distance Zones in one minute.

hook.text: A stranger stands six inches from your face. Instant discomfort. They just invaded your intimate zone.

buildup.text: Edward T. Hall defined four distance zones: intimate (0-18in), personal (18in-4ft), social (4-12ft), public (12ft+).

discovery.text: We unconsciously enforce these boundaries. Violating them triggers anxiety or fight-or-flight responses.

twist.text: These distances vary by culture: Latin Americans stand closer; Northern Europeans prefer more space.

climax.text: Elevator behavior proves it: strangers press against walls and stare at numbers to manage forced intimacy.

punchline.text: Distance isn't just physical. It's emotional architecture.

quiz.question: Who defined the four interpersonal distance zones?
